title: Adam Laxalt
deleted: In 2017, Laxalt spoke at the NRA-ILA Leadership Forum in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. In his speech, Laxalt criticized a bill passed by the Nevada Senate, comparing the bill to the film ''[[Minority Report (film)|Minority Report]]'', saying the bill was based in “a concept called pre-crime” and would allow the government to “take your second amendment rights based merely on suspicion or threat.”<ref>{{Citation|last=NRA|title=Adam Laxalt: 2017 NRA-ILA Leadership Forum|date=2017-04-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9K9LMeK56pw|access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> In 2018, months after the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] published a video calling greater adoption of these laws,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-support-for-red-flag-gun-confiscation-laws-came-after-he-panned-similar-idea-in-2017-nra-speech|title=Laxalt support for 'Red Flag' gun confiscation laws came after he panned similar idea in 2017 NRA speech|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt recommended that the legislature consider such a law in 2018, though he would not comment on if such laws were constitutional.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/08/14/laxalt-makes-campaign-return-reno-vet-event/993181002/|title=Laxalt on his (sometimes icy) relationship with Sandoval: 'I hope to earn his vote'|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt was slated to speak at the NRA's 2018 annual conference until his photo was mysteriously removed from the event website, days after the [[Parkland shooting]], raising questions about what happened and whether he still planned to attend.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kkoh.com/2018/02/28/dems-say-laxalt-needs-to-reveal-interactions-with-the-nra/|title=Dems Say Laxalt Needs to Reveal Interactions With the NRA|date=2018-02-28|work=kkoh-am|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref>

As attorney general, Laxalt signed Nevada onto at least four known lawsuits supporting abortion restrictions or pro-life entities in other states.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com">{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-signs-nevada-on-to-support-alabama-abortion-restrictions-had-backed-similar-law-in-texas|title=Laxalt signs Nevada on to support Alabama abortion restrictions; had backed similar law in Texas|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt signed onto two lawsuits supporting bans on the most commonly used second-trimester abortion procedure.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com"/> Republican pro-choice Governor Brian Sandoval's office said it was not consulted before Laxalt signed Nevada onto the Texas abortion ban brief. In the Supreme Court case [[Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt]], Laxalt signed an amicus brief<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/15-274-bsac-IndOh21otherStates.pdf|title=Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt|last=|first=|date=|website=SCOTUS Blog|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> in support of a Texas [[TRAP law]] that imposed medically unnecessary restrictions on abortion clinics in order to curb the availability of abortion providers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2014/08/28/343990460/texas-law-could-lead-to-closure-of-clinics-that-offer-abortions|title=Texas Law Could Lead To Closure Of Clinics That Offer Abortions|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> The Supreme Court found the restrictions were an unconstitutional violation of the prohibition on placing an “undue burden” on the right to obtain an abortion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/28/us/supreme-court-texas-abortion.html|title=Supreme Court Strikes Down Texas Abortion Restrictions|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

Laxalt signed onto a California lawsuit to support keeping secret the identities of the donors to one of his biggest political backers, the [[Americans for Prosperity]] Foundation, backed by the GOP megadonors Charles and David Koch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/adam-laxalt-adds-name-to-lawsuit-concerning-top-gop-donors/|title=Adam Laxalt adds name to lawsuit concerning top GOP donors|date=2018-06-25|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Laxalt opposed a multi-state investigation into [[ExxonMobil]]'s alleged role in downplaying climate change, condemning it as an attempt to stifle an “ongoing public policy debate” over human-caused global warming. Laxalt took legal action to keep fraud investigators from scrutinizing groups connected to the Koch network, which went on to spend $2.5 million to support Laxalt's governor campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/09/10/adam-laxalt-nevada-republican-nominee-exxon-mobil-koch-brothers-donor-foil/1203690002/|title=Laxalt joined Koch brothers, his campaign allies, in bid to block ExxonMobil fraud probe|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

title: Adam Laxalt
added: In 2017, Laxalt spoke at the NRA-ILA Leadership Forum in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. In his speech, Laxalt criticized a bill passed by the Nevada Senate, comparing the bill to the film ''[[Minority Report (film)|Minority Report]]'', saying the bill was based in “a concept called pre-crime” and would allow the government to “take your second amendment rights based merely on suspicion or threat.”<ref>{{Citation|last=NRA|title=Adam Laxalt: 2017 NRA-ILA Leadership Forum|date=2017-04-28|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9K9LMeK56pw|access-date=2018-09-17}}</ref> In 2018, months after the [[National Rifle Association|NRA]] published a video calling greater adoption of these laws,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-support-for-red-flag-gun-confiscation-laws-came-after-he-panned-similar-idea-in-2017-nra-speech|title=Laxalt support for 'Red Flag' gun confiscation laws came after he panned similar idea in 2017 NRA speech|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt recommended that the legislature consider such a law in 2018, though he would not comment on if such laws were constitutional.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/08/14/laxalt-makes-campaign-return-reno-vet-event/993181002/|title=Laxalt on his (sometimes icy) relationship with Sandoval: 'I hope to earn his vote'|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt was slated to speak at the NRA's 2018 annual conference until his photo was mysteriously removed from the event website, days after the [[Parkland shooting]], raising questions about what happened and whether he still planned to attend.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kkoh.com/2018/02/28/dems-say-laxalt-needs-to-reveal-interactions-with-the-nra/|title=Dems Say Laxalt Needs to Reveal Interactions With the NRA|date=2018-02-28|work=kkoh-am|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref>

As attorney general, Laxalt signed Nevada onto at least four known lawsuits supporting abortion restrictions or pro-life entities in other states.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com">{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-signs-nevada-on-to-support-alabama-abortion-restrictions-had-backed-similar-law-in-texas|title=Laxalt signs Nevada on to support Alabama abortion restrictions; had backed similar law in Texas|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt signed onto two lawsuits supporting bans on the most commonly used second-trimester abortion procedure.<ref name="thenevadaindependent.com"/> Republican pro-choice Governor Brian Sandoval's office said it was not consulted before Laxalt signed Nevada onto the Texas abortion ban brief. In the Supreme Court case [[Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt]], Laxalt signed an amicus brief<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scotusblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/15-274-bsac-IndOh21otherStates.pdf|title=Whole Woman's Health v. Hellerstedt|last=|first=|date=|website=SCOTUS Blog|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref> in support of a Texas [[TRAP law]] that imposed medically unnecessary restrictions on abortion clinics in order to curb the availability of abortion providers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2014/08/28/343990460/texas-law-could-lead-to-closure-of-clinics-that-offer-abortions|title=Texas Law Could Lead To Closure Of Clinics That Offer Abortions|work=NPR.org|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref> The Supreme Court found the restrictions were an unconstitutional violation of the prohibition on placing an “undue burden” on the right to obtain an abortion.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/28/us/supreme-court-texas-abortion.html|title=Supreme Court Strikes Down Texas Abortion Restrictions|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

Laxalt signed onto a California lawsuit to support keeping secret the identities of the donors to one of his biggest political backers, the [[Americans for Prosperity]] Foundation, backed by the GOP megadonors Charles and David Koch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/adam-laxalt-adds-name-to-lawsuit-concerning-top-gop-donors/|title=Adam Laxalt adds name to lawsuit concerning top GOP donors|date=2018-06-25|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Laxalt opposed a multi-state investigation into [[ExxonMobil]]'s alleged role in downplaying climate change, condemning it as an attempt to stifle an “ongoing public policy debate” over human-caused global warming. Laxalt took legal action to keep fraud investigators from scrutinizing groups connected to the Koch network, which went on to spend $2.5 million to support Laxalt's governor campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/09/10/adam-laxalt-nevada-republican-nominee-exxon-mobil-koch-brothers-donor-foil/1203690002/|title=Laxalt joined Koch brothers, his campaign allies, in bid to block ExxonMobil fraud probe|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>

Laxalt was endorsed by Storey County Sheriff Gerald Antinoro in November 2017 after he announced his candidacy.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/major-reno-developer-to-laxalt-investigate-sexual-harassment-claims-against-embattled-storey-county-sheriff|title=Major Reno developer to Laxalt: Investigate sexual harassment claims against embattled Storey County sheriff|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> Laxalt faced scrutiny for declining to disavow Antinoro's campaign support.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/09/28/records-show-adam-laxalt-arrested-assault-charge-teenager/1433833002/|title=Records show Adam Laxalt was arrested for allegedly assaulting a police officer as a teen|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> Antinoro was accused of rape in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mynews4.com/news/local/on-your-side-storey-county-sheriff-race-turns-ugly|title=On Your Side: Storey County Sheriff race turns ugly|last=Group|first=Sinclair Broadcast|work=KRNV|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}}</ref> A 2016 independent investigation found that Antinoro sexually harassed his top deputy.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Storey County Administrator Austin Osborne said in a deposition that “numerous…more than 10” complaints including sexual harassment allegations were filed against Antinoro.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/indy-exclusive-melanie-keener-former-storey-county-deputy-sheriff-talks-about-conditions-that-led-to-her-lawsuit|title=Former Storey County deputy sheriff, her career in tatters, talks about filing complaint against sheriff|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> After the sexual harassment investigation, Antinoro faced a recall election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ktnv.com/news/group-files-recall-petition-against-storey-county-sheriff_96314381|title=Group files recall petition against Storey County Sheriff|date=2016-11-24|work=KTNV|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181010011244/https://www.ktnv.com/news/group-files-recall-petition-against-storey-county-sheriff_96314381|archive-date=2018-10-10|url-status=dead}}</ref> In April 2018, Tahoe-Reno Industrial Center called on Laxalt to rescind the endorsement and to investigate multiple allegations of sexual harassment against Antinoro.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In May 2018, Laxalt dismissed criticism of his refusal to reject the endorsement or denounce Antinoro as “political theatrics.”<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.lasvegasnow.com/news/nevada-gubernatorial-republican-forum/1208882376|title=Nevada Gubernatorial Republican Forum|last=Bleakley|first=Caroline|date=2018-05-30|work=LASVEGASNOW|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}}</ref> Laxalt was scheduled to campaign with Antinoro at the end of May 2018 but Antinoro announced he would not attend after the event was picked up in media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/top-republicans-in-statewide-races-as-well-as-embattled-sheriff-will-be-guests-at-storey-county-political-barbecue|title=Embattled Storey County sheriff backs out of attending political barbecue this weekend|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> In July 2018, Laxalt released the long-awaited investigative report into Antinoro and announced that he would not pursue criminal charges.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/07/09/laxalt-finds-storey-county-sheriff-gerald-antinoro-didnt-commit-crime/769994002/|title=Laxalt finds no crimes committed by embattled Storey County sheriff Gerald Antinoro|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> The investigation was criticized for not interviewing Antinoro, alleged co-perpetrators or multiple rape victims.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/383668735/Joey-Gilbert-letter-to-AG-7-10#from_embed|title=Joey Gilbert letter to AG 7/10|website=Scribd|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}}</ref> After the investigation concluded, Laxalt announced he would no longer campaign with Antinoro or use his endorsement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thenevadaindependent.com/article/laxalt-no-plans-to-file-criminal-charges-against-embattled-storey-county-sheriff/|title=Laxalt: No plans to file criminal charges against embattled Storey County sheriff, won't campaign with him|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en}}</ref> An October 2018 letter showed that the Attorney's General office met with former deputy sheriff Melanie Keener in early 2016, at which time the deputy shared details of Antinoro's history of sexually harassing employees.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nvdems.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/10/2018.10.18_Gus20Flangas.pdf|title=10/17/18 Letter from the Nevada Attorney General's office|last=|first=|date=17 October 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>

title: Adam Laxalt
deleted: Laxalt signed onto a California lawsuit to support keeping secret the identities of the donors to one of his biggest political backers, the [[Americans for Prosperity]] Foundation, backed by the GOP megadonors Charles and David Koch.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reviewjournal.com/news/politics-and-government/nevada/adam-laxalt-adds-name-to-lawsuit-concerning-top-gop-donors/|title=Adam Laxalt adds name to lawsuit concerning top GOP donors|date=2018-06-25|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}}</ref> Laxalt opposed a multi-state investigation into [[ExxonMobil]]'s alleged role in downplaying climate change, condemning it as an attempt to stifle an “ongoing public policy debate” over human-caused global warming. Laxalt took legal action to keep fraud investigators from scrutinizing groups connected to the Koch network, which went on to spend $2.5 million to support Laxalt's governor campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rgj.com/story/news/politics/2018/09/10/adam-laxalt-nevada-republican-nominee-exxon-mobil-koch-brothers-donor-foil/1203690002/|title=Laxalt joined Koch brothers, his campaign allies, in bid to block ExxonMobil fraud probe|work=Reno Gazette Journal|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en}}</ref>
